title: 113_hr3131
content: The Act titled "National Park Service Study Act of 2013" authorizes special resource studies. The Secretary of the Interior will conduct special resource studies on various sites including the Kau coast in Hawaii, prehistoric sites on Rota in the Northern Mariana Islands, Aleut villages in Alaska, Japanese American relocation centers from World War II, Mahaulepu in Kauai, Goldfield mining sites in Nevada, and the Hudson River Valley in New York. The Secretary of the Interior will conduct special resource studies on various sites including the Norman Studios in Florida, Mobile-Tensaw River Delta in Alabama, Galveston Bay in Texas, Pullman site in Illinois, northern coast of Maui in Hawaii, and historic sites on Midway Atoll. The studies will evaluate national significance, feasibility of designating sites as National Park System units, and consider preservation alternatives in consultation with governmental and non-governmental entities. The Secretary of the Interior will conduct special resource studies on various sites to evaluate national significance and feasibility of designating them as National Park System units. The studies will consider preservation alternatives in consultation with governmental and non-governmental entities, and identify cost estimates for associated Federal activities. The studies will be conducted in accordance with applicable law. SEC. 3. SPECIAL RESOURCE STUDY UPDATES. The Secretary of the Interior will update studies on World War II Sites in Palau and Vermejo Ranch in New Mexico/Colorado. The update will determine if the sites should be designated as part of the National Park System, explore preservation alternatives, consult with relevant entities, and estimate costs for federal involvement. The Secretary of the Interior will update studies on World War II Sites in Palau and Vermejo Ranch in New Mexico/Colorado to explore preservation alternatives, consult with relevant entities, and estimate costs for federal involvement in development, interpretation, operation, and maintenance. SEC. 4. BUFFALO SOLDIERS IN THE NATIONAL PARKS STUDY. The Secretary of the Interior will conduct a study on commemorating the Buffalo Soldiers' role in early national parks. This includes assessing their history, considering a national historic trail from San Francisco to national parks, identifying historic properties, and enhancing public awareness of their stewardship. The Buffalo Soldiers played a significant stewardship role in early national parks, linking their story to the development of the parks and African-American military service post-Civil War. SEC. 5. RECONSTRUCTION IN THE SOUTH STUDY. The Secretary of the Interior will conduct a study to identify significant sites and resources in the Southern United States related to the Reconstruction era. Recommendations will be made for commemorating and interpreting these sites, including new national historic landmarks nominations and further study for potential inclusion in the National Park System. SEC. 6. CHATTAHOOCHEE RIVER BOUNDARY EXPANSION STUDY. The Secretary of the Interior will conduct a study to determine the suitability and feasibility of expanding the Chattahoochee River National Recreation Area by approximately 45 miles. The study will analyze resources, management issues, protection of critical resources, feasibility of administration, and alternative management options. The study will assess the suitability and feasibility of expanding the Chattahoochee River National Recreation Area by 45 miles, including analyzing resources, management issues, protection of critical resources, feasibility of administration, and alternative management options. It will also evaluate the adequacy of other alternatives for managing and protecting resources within the study area. The Secretary of the Interior must submit a report to the House and Senate committees within 3 years of funding for each study under the Act, including study results, conclusions, and recommendations.
